newsitem.title: UK: Hess N.Sea Durward field sees small delay.
newsitem.headline: Hess N.Sea Durward field sees small delay.

text.p: First production at the Durward oil field in the central North Sea has been delayed slightly while commissioning work is completed, operator Amerada Hess said on Tuesday.
The field, with estimated recoverable reserves of some 32 million barrels of oil, was originally expected to start producing between April and June.
"We're now expecting first oil early in the third quarter. There's been a small delay in the completion of the topsides," a company spokeswoman told Reuters.

Durward is being developed with the nearby Dauntless field using floating production storage and offloading vessels, a project described last summer by Hess as the company's "fastest ever stand alone development".
Production from both fields is expected to plateau at more than 50,000 barrels per day (bpd) shortly after startup.
Hess' partners in the fields are Saga Petroleum ASA, DSM Energy (UK) Ltd, British-Borneo Group and Seafield Resources Plc.
Two other new North Sea fields, Conoco's MacCulloch and BP's Foinaven, also due on stream in the first half of 1997 have suffered more serious delays.
MacCulloch is expected to start producing later this month while Foinaven will not be on stream until late August at the earliest.
